On the night of May 3rd.

In Oklahoma.

My father is 90 years old. In his very long lifetime of watching Oklahoma weather he had never seen frost here later than April 14th.

So we put out our tomato plants the week of the 15th. They were a killed by a freeze on April 19th.

We dug them up and replanted new ones last week. We're fixing to lose them again.

Yeah, I know, weather is not climate.

So tell me, Dot Earthers, what do you make of killing frosts three weeks later in the year than ever before?

Spare me the solemn assurances that such vicious late cold is "consistent with" global warming predictions.

Spare me the jabberwocky about loss of arctic sea ice making the jet stream boogaloo this way or that. I heard the same story during last year's drought; can't work both ways.

I recall 12-13 years ago being warned that my "children are just not going to know what snow is." Then told CAGW means more snow.

We were told to expect tropical diseases like dengue.

Codswallop.

The trouble is not that the CAGW/climate change/extreme weather shape-shifting scare-story-de-jour is non-predictive. The trouble is it predicts everything.

Sandy Levinson is pointing out what the Constitution says about the election of the Speaker and discusses Mickey Edwards' ideas on that. There is no support for Alan West being Speaker: "It was surely a sign of Gohmert's personal idiocy..."

A fine column, save for one caveat: It was surely a sign of Gohmert's personal idiocy that he thought that Alan West should be Speaker. But there is nothing unconstitutional, or even necessarily unwise, about thinking that the Speaker should be drawn from outside the House. Indeed, former Republican Representative Mickey Edwards, a fine public servant who has recently published The Parties Versus the People: How to Turn Democrats and Republicans into Americans (Yale University Press), suggests that one way to temper the toxic polarization of the House of Representatives wouuld be the election of a Speaker from outside the House who could be trusted to serve the national interest instead of the far narrower interest of his or her own political party. The Constitution says only that the House shall select its Speaker; it doesn't require that the Speaker be a member.

Sanford Levinson
University of Texas Law School

The situation you describe is not inflation. When workers' pay does not go up but the prices of a number of things they buy do go up, it is just the poor getting poorer. That is bad, but it is not inflation.

The difference is that such price increases can't go on forever. Without accompanying wage increases, consumers eventually will not have the money to buy the stuff, and the prices will rise no further.

But when there is enough money, enough purchasing power, that workers' pay can rise too, then a wage/price spiral can take place, each driving the other, and that is potentially unending. That's inflation.

Much of the time inflation is bad, but Krugman argues that right now, enough government stimulus spending and money creation to produce moderate inflation would encourage spending and investment, and pull us out of the depression. Of course, once real recovery happened, we would have to increase both taxes and the interest rate to pull inflation back down. Even if that caused another recession, that's a kind of downturn that's much easier to escape than the one we're in.

But this won't happen. The Republicans don't want it to happen, and are in a position to prevent it. Back in 2009, Obama and the Democrats had an opportunity to push through (by so-called reconciliation) an economic policy similar to what Krugman advocates (he advocated it back then, too), which would have made the Obama presidency a brilliant success. But they didn't try then, and it's too late now.

"What kind of pin-stripe-suited monster sleeps easily knowing that his company is sowing misery -- even death -- among the people who sew the products he sells under the banner of "low low prices?"

The rationalization is rather simple. This monster is "creating opportunities" for a people that would otherwise be even further impoverished. Why can't the monster offer wages and conditions more conducive to their mere survival? The somber reality is that these practices have become so ubiquitous that even the slightest gestures towards these people's well-being (better pay, working conditions, facilities) may not even result in a sustainable business model.

It would take a remarkable force of will to penetrate such a foundation of human exploitation. But unfortunately, the force of the "low-price" beholden consumer is pretty unshakable.

I think most buyers have at least some exposure to the inhuman cost of their cheap goods. And there is no hesitation. And everyone sleeps soundly.

But the responsibility does lie with "those of us who purchased the garments at home or abroad." And it lies with the brands, which pressure suppliers to produce goods at the lowest possible price.

It doesn't take a genius to figure out that workers -- the people who sew those dirt-cheap garments -- are the ones who are short-changed so that everyone saves money and the brands make billions.

If consumers refused to buy goods manufactured at slave wages from brands who procure them at slave wages, then brands would demand that workers be paid fairly and treated humanely.

But all this begs the question.

What kind of pin-stripe-suited monster sleeps easily knowing that his company is sowing misery -- even death -- among the people who sew the products he sells under the banner of "low low prices?"

It is true that a little inflation helps the economy. It is true that the Fed has implemented the correct policies to help the economy recover from the disastrous collapse of the credit system and the contraction of the money supply, caused by the fall in aggregate demand, called the financial crisis.

Replenishing the money supply and recapitalizing the banking system does not cause inflation. It is called damage control.

Purchasing the debt of the United States, as the Fed is doing, is not going to cause inflation. It is called funding the federal government. Without funding, we would have chaos, a breakdown in the system.

The economy is big and $2 trillion doesn't buy as much as it used to. $2 trillion is also less than a fraction of one percent of the value of American assets in a growing economy.

Restoring aggregate demand is the goal of those who would help the economy to grow. Unfortunately these elementary facts are unknown to many members of Congress.

Few people understand the potentially terrible consequences of the financial crisis that were averted, and how the American economy - and the world economy - was saved by the Federal Reserve. Uncle Sam stepped up when someone had to step up.

In the middle of a terrible economy, healthcare costs have risen appreciably over the last 5 years. I gauge this by the annual double digit rise in my insurance premiums over the period.

Healthcare comprises $2.8 trillion out of a $15 trillion economy. That's almost 19%. Could it be that excess liquidity is fueling the rise in healthcare costs? Could it be that healthcare costs effectively function as a huge tax upon all other sections of the economy thereby greatly restraining their growth? Could it also be that this transference of liquidity into healthcare keeps prices from rising elsewhere in the economy?

How can prices rise so quickly in 19% of the economy if there wasn't sufficient liquidity available to support the rise in prices?
